message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver is known to increase the intensity of murmurs. Handgrip and passive leg raise can decrease the intensity, while placing the patient in a squatting position can either decrease or increase depending on the type of murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of murmurs associated with right-sided heart abnormalities, such as pulmonary stenosis or Tetralogy of Fallot, which are often benign in nature. Handgrip increases the intensity of murmurs associated with mitral regurgitation and aortic stenosis. Placing the patient in a squatting position or passive leg raise decreases the intensity of murmurs associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The maneuvers in the options are used to differentiate murmurs. Valsalva maneuver will increase the intensity of the murmur if it is caused by hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can lead to sudden cardiac death. Therefore, this is the correct answer. Handgrip will increase the intensity of murmurs caused by aortic stenosis or mitral regurgitation, placing the patient in a squatting position will decrease the intensity of murmurs caused by aortic stenosis or mitral regurgitation, and passive leg raise will increase the intensity of murmurs caused by hypovolemia or mitral stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of a murmur, while handgrip, squatting position, and passive leg raise decrease the intensity of a murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of the murmur in Mitral Valve Prolapse, which is a benign condition that can sometimes lead to sudden cardiac death. Handgrip, placing the patient in a squatting position, and passive leg raise are used to diagnose and distinguish other types of murmurs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver (forced expiratory effort with a closed airway) will increase the intensity of the murmur in conditions such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and mitral stenosis. Handgrip, squatting position, and passive leg raise can decrease the intensity of the murmur in some conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of murmurs, including the innocent or benign ones. The other options can either decrease or not affect the intensity of the murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of a heart murmur, while handgrip, placing the patient in a squatting position, and passive leg raise decrease the intensity of the murmur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of the murmur in most instances, including those that are otherwise benign. Handgrip and squatting positions often reduce the intensity of the murmur. Passive leg raise has no effect on the murmur intensity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Valsalva maneuver can increase the intensity of a murmur, especially in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can cause sudden cardiac death in young athletes.
